I bought this game because it was $1 and it had trading cards. I expected some crappy Thomas Was Alone clone, but what I got was a very well executed platformer / arena shooter hybrid. This may well be the best $1 game I've ever bought (not counting Humble Bundles).

The basic idea of the game is that you are a square who can move around rather quickly, has infinite jumps, and can shoot orbs of light at pointy geometric enemies who want to murder you. Oh and you can slow down time. Each level is a puzzle, obstacle course, and/or boss battle. For example, there's a level where you have to navigate a maze while a square shoots flashing squares at you and you have to defend yourself while navigate within range of the boss square to take it down.

While the platforming parts were kind of meh, the combat is where the game shines. To attack, you click near David (the protagonist square) to charge him up, and then release it to shoot the light orbs around you like a rainbow shotgun blast. The trick is that when you are charging time is slowed down. This means that attacking and defending are tied to the same mechanic and it works amazingly well. Furthermore, the light orbs are actually floating around you and are attracted to you via a gravitational field, and only those near you will be shot when you release your charge. This means that if you move or change directions too fast, your orbs won't catch up and your attack power is diminished. But you can also use this to your advantage: let some of your orbs catch up, fire a shot in one direction, and then immediately fire the rest in another once they catch up.

The bosses are either in the charge mindlessly at you" or the "stand still and rain bullets on you" variety. However

David. is what happens when biblical theology is applied to an abstract arcade game.

In this it largely loses the importance or substance of its inspiration, that being the story of David and Goliath, the miniature farmerâ€™s boy who toppled a giant, using it mostly as an interesting mechanical hook rather than a meaningful plot. Youâ€™re placed into varying challenges as the tiny block, David, and must use your slingshot to dismantle the geometric behemoths whose attack patterns are vaguely tied to level names derived from concepts of sin and fear.

Unfortunately David. rather lost me the more discombobulated its design becomes in its attempts at variety and tying itself to a plot that doesnâ€™t exist. I applaud developer Fermenter for creating a game based on things they clearly deeply believe, but they only lay the groundwork for a deeper meaning and then leave it languishing somewhere between an implied connection and so clearly laid out it loses its point. The lack of any subtlety or consistency in tone made it difficult for me to become invested in the game, or even just take it seriously most of the time.

Thereâ€™s a similarly muddy situation among David.â€™s different levels, which can be brilliant but more often hinge on a frustrating gimmick which disrupts the natural flow of the gameâ€™s best moments. More issues arrive through David.â€™s bizarre controls, which have an unwieldy momentum to them that runs counter to the often brutally tight level designs. On the normal difficulty itâ€™s a nuisance, but David. goes a step further and requires you beat every stage with a single sliver of health in order to unlock the final boss, a task I doubt I need to tell you the tediousness of.

There are genuinely novel ideas within David. like itâ€™s interesting use of a slingshot or the asymmetrical boss fights (ala Shadow of the Colossus), but it canâ€™t seem to see them well enough not to go running in the wrong direction. Completing it left me with an empty feeling I couldnâ€™t quite explain, my only guess being sadness that David.â€™s worst enemy ended up being itself.

reviewText:
Like Shadow of the Colossus and Titan Souls, David is a game of boss fights.  It contextualizes its simple move set with a creative array of well-designed situations that each require a different strategy; as a result, it's consistently fresh in addition to challenging.  The ability that drives the game is a kind of particle slingshot that requires you to click near David, hold the mouse button (which slows time), aim, and release the attack when charged.  Everything comes from this one mechanic, combined with fast, sliding, infinitely jumping movement through WASD.

How long David lasts you depends upon how good you are, but there is also a separate endless arena mode that pits you against many enemies in a departure from the unique boss setups.  There's even an upgrade system.  It was quite a relief when I earned the achievement in this mode since it can be as infuriating as it is addicting; I was happy to be able to step away with that job completed, although I definitely intend to come back again sometime.

It's hard to imagine what else could possibly be done with the basic idea at the heart of David, and it's always satisfying to see a mechanic so thoroughly explored.  The game is easily worth its asking price of $5, and I recommend it without reservation.  Edit: I just learned that David is due to permanently drop in price from $5 to $2 in a week, which makes it a no-brainer of a purchase.

reviewText:
David is a small, hollowed out square, with a special power. David contains several little ovals, which he can fling at enemies. He has been tasked with fighting and destroying evil, which he does by destroying 12 (very large) bosses. Presumably David's story is based on the biblical David, as you are a tiny hero taking on humongous foes, and the developer is quite clearly Christian (in addition to fighting sin, Jesus is the first thanked in his acknowledgements).

The boss fights are fast-paced and frantic. They're also very challenging and often frustrating when playing on the high difficulty (which you have to do, in order to get to the final boss). After playing the first boss, you'd be forgiven for thinking that the game will become repetitive quickly, and while this is true to a certain extent, the bosses in David are actually fairly original and varied. There are an impressive array of novelties that make each boss fight unique and feel fresh. For example, in one of the bonus boss fights, your ellipsoidal ammunition no longer follows you, meaning you have to go to it, and fire it from where it lies. Little variations like this really keep the game fun.

The downside is that this game is extremely short. Even with the arena mode, I would not expect more than a few hours. Five dollars is not an unreasonable asking price for something so different from the usual fare, but if you're uncertain, you can pick it up on sale. It is worth a try.

reviewText:
David is a 2D arena shooter where you control a little floaty cube called David. David can slide from side to side and can jump repeatedly in mid-air, giving him a levitation ability but with a constant gravity pull. To attack an enemy, you click and hold on David to enter a slow-motion state where David charges his attack. His attack shoots a sphere in the direction you are pointing; this sphere being composed of smaller spheres that orbit David. How big your shot is depends on how many of the small spheres are within a certain boundary around David at the time you release the shot.  After firing, you need to wait for the spheres to come back to orbit around David before shooting again.

The game has two modes. The main mode has you entering constrained arenas to fight bosses, and each boss has a certain gimmick that makes it unique. You will need to beat each boss twice, once with 7 hit points (easily managed) and 1 hit point (where the real fun is!). All the bosses are accessible at any time, except the final boss which requires that you successfully beat each minor boss at both difficulties.

There is also an arena mode where enemies keep coming at you while you accumulate points. The points allow you to upgrade David to last longer in the next run.

The game is definitely worth a purchase. It's a steal at $1, so get it while the offer lasts.

'David.'

A cute little game that feels more arcadey than most. The principle is simple; slingshot your orby things at anything that moves, and avoid anything you can.
There is of course plenty of variation on the theme, as no two levels are alike, but that remains the heart and core of it.

I heartily recommend this game to anyone who ever enjoyed the classic Asteroids or any softcore bullet hell shooters, or to anyone who wished Thomas Was Alone had more shooty action.
'David' is short but sweet and slightly challenging, like a sundae that makes you work for the flavour, with enough charm to add sprinkles to that metaphor.

Had I encountered this game as a child, I would've lost hours to it with fascination and frustration and gratification to show for it. Having encountered it today, I spent just over one hour, and feel quite satisfied. If not for yourself, grab it for the kids. But mostly for yourself.

Oh, and if you're still not convinced: there's hats.

So, David. If you can get past the period in the title that serves no purpose other than to bother the OCD, this game plays as a sort of Contra with flying powers. Oh, and it's all boss fights. There is one secret to be found (have fun with that, it's rather well hidden) and all of the unlockables are hats and upgrades for the arena. Somehow this game managed to justify shooting rainbow orbs at moving shapes and made it important. Props for that one.

The gameplay is a little finnicky, but after the first two or three levels I kind of got used to it. The jumping is a little awkward at first, and the slow-time effect every time you fire is a little disorienting. But this would just be another bullet storm game without those two elements (and the polygons) so I'll leave them be.

Story: Sort of, but only as a crazy slow intro that you have to play twice to get the achievement and as part of the credits.

I think if someone were to mix Contra with Shadow of the Colossus, this would be the result. So if you enjoyed those two games, or even liked the concept of them, give this game a shot. The price is dropping down to $1.99 March 16 (Would've been sooner, blame Steam) and I had quite a bit of fun with this game. My only complaints are the time slow in Arena making the game take forever, and that to even fight the final boss you have to fight all the others on the hardest difficulty. But otherwise, I enjoyed it and I'm sure I'll pick it up again some time in the future.

reviewText:
The price drop finally happened (neat to know Valve enforces rules to prevent bait-and-switch launch prices still) so I've decided to update. It's still not amazing, but the game works well enough to be a good value. It grew on me a bit, and the promises of more content should improve things, but it's surprisingly short and easy once accustomed to the game.

David is a series of boss-rooms, contrary to my expectations. There is no real story, limited tactics, and not much replayability in the bosses. The particle shot system made me expect strategy on kills to gain particles, but nothing happens like that. Click-and-hold to charge, release to fire the particles in range. The only real tactical element is timing so that particles rebound into your range. Jumping is more like floating, and can be repeated infinitely to fly. With gameplay being the core, it could be better and more strategic. The awkward physics system driving everything means that dead enemies can still hit you for damage, and the biggest threats are the accelerating enemies offscreen.

The game is fairly short, and I have completed everything so far in around 2 hours. A fair amount of that time was adjusting to the controls, learning how to handle the physics and slowmo. I really don't like the comparisons to Shadow of Colossus. That game had personality to the bosses and stunning environments to tell a story. David is decent as a short game, but this is not a classic. David is Mega Man without the adventure areas or upgrades. Beyond price, my remaining criticism is that the game is not unique nor impressive. I purchased on a whim, and it's decent enough for that. It's not a game I'd mention to friends, but I can't really criticize the value anymore. If you are truly interested, the game is a good deal now. 50% off for 1.00USD recommended.

reviewText:
A game that would have been good, but was dragged down by its own flaws
I really want to like David. It's a challenging game that has some very strong points. The premise of David. is simple, you control a small square with the WASD-keys that is orbited by spheres. If you press and hold your mouse over the square, time slows down and you charge up. If you're charged up, you get an audio queue and you will shoot any orbs within the square's range if you either release it, or wait too long. You're subjected to gravity, but you can jump an infinite amount of times.

The game sounds like fun on paper, but for me it was drowned out by the annoying parts. Although they might seem like small gripes, they really do add on and can grind your gears quickly. So let's play the good, the bad and the ugly to actually see why:

The good The music. It is very ambient and the boss fight track is pretty catchy. Even after beating the final boss and the main bosses I was not sick of hearing the music
A nice variety in bosses. Some are hair-pullingly annoying, but they are pretty well thought out. Although on the easy side because of the time slowing mechanic, every boss brought something new to the table.
Solid mechanics. The game works well. The game will not glitch out (at least, not that I noticed). And the framerate is very smooth not noticing any drops during play, which is necessary during play, because the action is high-paced.

The bad No graphics options. Ok, I understand that this is a 2D game, but isn't resolution options one of the basic things in a pc game? Some monitors do not like it when you have a smaller picture than the actual monitor's which leads to stretching, letterboxing etc. Some quality settings would also be nice for people on lower-end machines.
No rebindable controller buttons. The controller buttons are arbitrary and aren't shown in-game. You're left to scramble around the buttons to search for the charge button (which might just have been bound to every face button) is ONLY bound to RT.
The camera. It zooms and pans whenever it wants to. It is usually zoomed way too far in, making attacks from off-screen very frequent and also make you take way too many potshots. Also annoying during the bosses. If you don't move, they will attack you, even if you can't see your square i.e. your hitbox i.e. the thing that mustn't die. The final boss was actually a breath of fresh air, because in that fight the camera is pulled way back. However, it did make clicking and holding on the square way too hard.

The ugly Controller support.  Instead of making the scheme a simple left-stick move + right-stick aim, Your right stick controls the mouse. Not a mouse in the game, but your actual cursor. Even with auto-centering on, it wouldn't control well. Which is a huge shame, because twin-stick shooters play really well with controls. The menu also is really hard to navigate, because you have to select everything with the mouse... Which is controlled by your right stick.
Mouse and keyboard controls. My god they're bad. You have to click and hold onto your square, while dodging the bosses' attacks. If you pay attention during the tutorial you will actually see a finger being used instead of a mouse. A clear indicator that this was mobile first, pc dead last, made even more damning by the fact that you see a finger used in the tutorial to explain the shooting mechanics. It would have been much better if you could just click and hold anywhere on the screen, especially so during the final boss.
Length. Have you checked my game time? You can beat the game well within an hour and then there is another set of bosses and an endless mode called the arena. That's very sparse content. I'm aware the game is cheap, but this is really thin, in comparison to other games, even in the same price range
Difficulty curve. Or more accurately lack thereof. The WOLF, the third boss is a really annoying prick, being vulnerable at very specific times. Another annoying one is FLEE, which is a maze filled with death blocks and ends with a really easy fight. SIN on the other hand is a joke. Your vision is a huge upside and you can easily block his attacks with your shots. The MOAR room  contains more bosses, most of them also fall into the annoying category. Chief mention goes to STRAY where the orbs you fire gets scattered in the room. The only time that you actually really notice that the orbs need to be in your square's range in order to be fired

SummaryA bad port of a mobile game that is bereft of anything that would give a clear indication of it being made for pc, that finger in the tutorial speaks volumes. No controller support to speak of and a really short play time with difficulty all over the place makes me not recommend this game.

Recommended price point
Still want the game? Wait for it to be on sale. You can then usually pick up the game for around $0.50 which is not too bad for a game that might really disappoint you.

reviewText: Loved David. when it was an incredibly cheap indie game out there, bought it without thinking because it had some amazing recommendations by some intelligent people, enjoyed it thoroughly and then voted for it on Greenlight. And here we are a year later. It goes without saying that I bought it again just to express my support for the developer who made something so simple and yet so amazing and is selling it for such a low price. David. is the quintessential action game, distilled from decades of Mega Men, Street Fighters and other games where tactical thinking is as important as good reflexes. It is distilled to almost complete abstraction and yet it has both spirit AND character with enemy behaviours standing in for elaborate art direction and animations and the poor little David with his Halo the only little glimmer of hope in a universe consumed by darkness. This is it, this is the game where you don't get bogged down with having to wrestle with unrealistic motivations of the bad guys or the artificial dilemmas of your hero, this is all about brutal fighting to the death, all about movement, positioning, being cool under fire, knowing when to bait them, knowing how to avoid succumbing to your fears. David is, in case I wasn't entirely clear, very very good. Get it.

reviewText:
The Eurogamer review that calls this Shadow of the Colossus as designed by Ikea is rather apt.

Actually, if you go back to the arcade days, {David.} is closest to Sinistar (I hunger!).

Now, picture that with WASD controls, varied environments, and physics/gravity, and we're getting a bit closer. Then add 'bullet-time', as you tap on your shape to slow time and 'slingshot' your powers at a boss composed of multiple geometric shapes.

Most importantly, it all works. The environments are varied and have different rules (one level is a 'chase'; on another the boss is 'submerged' on one half of the screen)--it's all minimalist but the implementation is clever and each level feels unique and requires different strategies.

There's also an arena mode with escalating difficulty and power-ups.

All told, it's very hard to describe but a solid amount of fun, and a steal at its price.

David. is a very unique and interesting game. It has a very different style of play than anything I've ever seen before and it somehow makes playing as a little square fighting against big geometric shapes exciting and fun.

The game has you playing as a little square named David, and as this square you have to defeat a whole bunch of big geometric monsters that chase after you, shoot you, and jump on you. You accomplish this with a slingshot like weapon you are given in the intro, you use it by clicking and holding in a circle around David, letting it charge up, then releasing your click while it is aimed at where you desire to shoot and it sends these little oval ball projectiles wherever your mouse was aimed. After you shoot though, you have to make sure to let the projectiles go back into your circle otherwise they will not fire. And during the entire time you are holding your click, the game goes slow motion.

The game is somewhat aestetically pleasing, depending on your opinion of how geometric shapes look. It also has some nice music to set a certain mood while you are in a level, sort of pumping you up as it like a challenge themed music. Overall I like the music, but It's not like It's a soundtrack or anything, it is just little bits of music for the levels to further set the mood of the challenge.

Overall I like the game in almost all aspects, the only con I give to it is the playstyle. While I love the playstyle, it is also a con for me as the playstyle is basically you keeping the game in slow-motion all the time to stay alive. This is not something that can neccessarily be fixed as It's really hard to stay alive without being in slow-motion 90% of the time. This is the only problem I can think of with this game, everything else is spot on for its price.

I have played the game completely throughout, beating every level on both difficulties and getting all the achievements other than the achievement for reaching 100 in the Arena. From this amount of time I put into this game, I can easily tell you that it is worth it, I got the game for $1 on Steam and it has given me 3.5 hours of fun, and will be giving me more as I continue to try and get to 100 in Arena, and even now that the game is $1.99 on Steam it is still worth it. This game is perfectly priced as It's only $2 and still gives you at the very least an hour of fun on it. As long as the game looks interesting to you and you have a bit of money floating around in your steam wallet, I highly reccommend purchasing this game.

reviewText:
In the span of an hour, I ripped through David. and saw every little oddity and battle offered. For many games I've played, it's a depressing detriment, and I crave more, but somehow the makers found a way to cram enjoyment and challenge without ever overstaying their welcome. Polished, gorgeous, and simple, and with a buttload of variety.

The boss rush style set up can be make or break, but David. captures the excitement of high production fights with simple, genuinely fun boss fights that always bring something new to the table you have to adapt to. Going in, I played all the matches on the hardest difficulty, making it a one shot kill for me if I messed up or failed. In my humble opinion this is how the game was meant to be played, but regardless, there is a lot of reward to be had when clearing out a particularly difficult boss.

Gameplay wise, you are a square that floats around and can blast the evil triangles away with your giant throbbing balls of light. It takes tact, understanding of the physics and decent aim. That's it. You will die. A lot. Few games do you learn from death so well, so expect a good challenge and a lovely, minimalistic abstract art style. For the miniscule price, David is worth the pennies. It sticks with you well after you finish, even though it doesn't have anything in particular to say. The music's also wonderful, so if you're looking for a great game that's off the beaten path, look no further.

reviewText:
It's hard to recommend David. enough.

It's an incredibly abstract twin-stick style shooter with unique mechanics. A few are:

- Infinite double jumping. Tt's double in that the longer you hold the key the higher you go, so spamming jump (as you want to do from the getgo) is largely ineffective.
- Rubber-banding bullets that are only effective for a few frames. While you're charging them time slows down, allowing you to precicely aim. When you fire the enemies speed up before you do making it tricky to use.
- Truly unique bosses.
- After you beat those unique bosses you get a run-of-the-mill but extremely fun arena mode that lets you spend your high score on upgrades. Don't beat your high score? No new toys.

Visually it's geometric, clean, and easily conveys meaning through color (water is dark, you can't go through red walls, etc.) It can get hecktic, and busy, but the time-slow mechanic keeps it from being -too- overwhelming (though, you'll certainly be overwhelmed for a while).

On the negative side, the controls are slippery. It's difficult even to pass through the doorways in the game, and the physics are unpredictable. The time lag you experence after firing is part of it, but you carry significantly more moment out of the time-slow than the game suggests. Often times I felt as if I was being sucked to one side of the map until I got used to it.

To me, these flaws add to the challenge in a meaningful and significant way. It allows the game to flow at a breakneck pace, while allowing you to manage that pace on your own, but without giving you full control. A misclick will mean a loss of health if not death which keeps you from getting complacent.

Best of all, it's easy to pick up and play for a few minutes at a time, but it remains engaging for much longer than it's simple mechanics and feel would suggest.

It's hard to find a better value for the price. Buy this right now.

reviewText:
I first played this game just shortly and didn't like it much. Later I noticed how good reviews it have so I decided to give it second change, maybe I just missed something? But no, I still don't get it :)

Game itself is simple, controlling square around and shooting stuff. Or at least trying. Controls are slightly sluggish and unintuitive. Sometimes jumping in air works, sometimes I fall like a rock especially after shooting. When shooting, sometimes projectiles moves fast and far, sometimes they don't move at all.

Enemies might be outside the screen and then attack super speed. Sometimes I get stuck between wall and enemy and lose all health at once, I don't know is it supposed to be like that. In some cases even player own character is shortly outside screen.

In many levels, you don't know first time whatever you should collect or shoot something, causing unnecessary deaths. It feels that whole game requires lots of guessing and luck. Some UI buttons included, as they may be just pixely shapes and you have to click them few times to find out what they do.

So yeah, sadly I can't say I enjoyed playing this game. Maybe it just requires more practice, right state of mind or just different controller than keyboard and mouse. Game just feels to be missing finishing touch. It's kinda pity because I like the simplicity of basic idea. Graphics (if you can say there is any), music and sounds are okay for game like this. And I like that levels have variation.
